column4: how many people i have to help before some one helps me with kernel 3.1 ??
if you have a static ip why use dhcp?
gotcha now
i would think you would want the ip range to be 192.168.3.10 to  .255
hang on a sec. I may have made a typo
yeah, that was a typo. its 3.10, not 10.3
in the dhcpd.conf do you have a INTERFACES= "eth0" line?
no. I never heard of that being needed to dhcpd.conf?
also look into /etc/default/isc-dhcp-server
file
yeah, I have INTERFACSE="eth0" there, but not in dhcpd.conf
ok
do you have multiple nics?
just eth0 and wlan0. This is a laptop I'm using for a quick demo with dhcp, which is why Im using it as a dhcp server even though its a laptop
i thought you got it working
nope.
about to commit homicide in a minute here if I don't get it working.
doubt it. its disabled.
eth0 and lo
in /var/log/syslog are you getting No subnet declaration for eth0  ?
actually yeah.
what are they referring to with my subnet declaration?
see http://www.basicconfig.com/linuxnetwork/configure_dhcp_server_ubuntu
I'm not sure I fully understand.
in /etc/default/dhcp3-server do you have an interface line?
there is no dhcp3-server, but there is isc-dhcp-server, which is how newer versions of ubuntu work. but in that file I do have an interfaces line, and eth0 is listed there.;
you also need to add the mac address of the interface to use in the dhcpd.conf file host fantasia {
if that does not work post the dhcpd.conf on http://paste.ubuntu.com/
didnt work.
if that does not work post the dhcpd.conf on http://paste.ubuntu.com/
http://pastebin.com/gXH6pBey
host fantasia { should be the name of your computer form hostanem
made no difference.
you also need another } at line 23 or
even still, made no difference
fresh install
could you post the whole error you are getting?
i think the problem is farther back from the interface error line
http://pastebin.com/NhB85yT4
in which file?
thats in the dhcpd.conf you posted
still failed
how are you restarting it?
sudo /etc/init.d/networking restart, then sudo service isc-dhcp-server restart
dont need to restart the networking
post the /etc/default/isc-dhcp-server please
i take it you are setting up fog
trying to
oh the joys i have heard
about what?
setting up fog
FOG is an outstanding product. I've imaged about 5,000 systems with it. Nothing beats it.
the problem is Ubuntu continually changes up crap which causes FOG to have to continually re-vamp their setup scripts.
it's actually quite brainless to set it up. As you can see, this is not a FOG problem. It's a DHCP problem.
yes and things have to be in certain spots for fog to work correctly
again, that's a problem with Ubuntu continually changing crap.
I've used FOG for years. It's nothing short of beautiful. But each release of Ubuntu introduces new BS to overcome.
then why not stick with a lts release?
I could, but I had a 11.10 laptop handy and I wanted to demo it. Now I'm so ticked at this thing I'm determined to get it working.
i understand that
it'd be nice if FOG was a darn .deb...
dozens
have you tried renaming the fog dhcpd.conf and trying a defualt ubuntu one and editing it?
at this point I don't even care about FOG. I just want o get DHCP working for my own sanity.
the fog dhcpd.conf?????
the one you posted says This file was created by FOG
I just did a remove --purge of dhcp3-server. When I reinstalled, it didnt bring back a new dhcpd.conf.
thats the /etc/dhcp3/dhcpd.conf  didnt come back?
dhcp3 exists in /etc, but the only thing inside is dhclient-enter-hooks.d
where you editing the /etc/dhcp/dhcpd.conf  not the /etc/dhcp3/dhcpd.conf  file?
yes. one of the links I read said to do that (I think it was one you may have linked??)
/etc/dhcp3/dhcpd.conf does not exist.
that might be the problem
or not let me install it real quick
it would be in dhcp/dhcpd.conf
so I was editing the right area?
yes you dont have a /etc/ltsp/dhcpd.conf file do you i doubt it but check please
oh crap... I totally forgot about LTSP....
wowwwwwww thats gotta be it. huh?
i think so # Attention: If /etc/ltsp/dhcpd.conf exists, that will be used as
wow. that was it.
oh my gosh I want to slap myself.
you are AWESOME. what made you think of ltsp?
its in the first line of the dhcpd.conf file # Attention: If /etc/ltsp/dhcpd.conf exists, that will be used as # configuration file instead of this file.
you can brag about it tomorrow how it was hard and how you figured it out
i have learned alot about dhcpd so i am happy
I'd rather brag about how sick nasty amazing awesome the users in #ubuntu are in terms of helping people out.
well some of them are
the vast majority are, which warrants bragging of that nature. ;)
did you get it working?
yes, I'm good. THANK YOU
woohoo
